awd_abstract_narration:
This project is jointly funded by the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry, and the Genetic Mechanisms and Systems and Synthetic Biology Clusters in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

Life is thought to have emerged on the early earth as a consequence of the chemistry of the young planet. Subsequently, there was assembly into simple cells that could grow, divide and evolve.  Such cells were probably composed of a cell membrane that enclosed a primitive version of RNA that could store useful information and also carry out simple cellular functions.  At present, there is a lack of a full understanding of how genetic materials such as RNA could have been copied before the evolution of enzymes. This project involves a series of experiments aimed at achieving fast and accurate non-enzymatic copying of short RNA strands. The ability to copy RNA in a purely chemical manner is an essential step towards the goal of assembling simple living cells from inanimate chemicals. This in turn would contribute greatly to our understanding of the origin of life on the early earth, and to assessing the likelihood that life might exist on other planets. Since the Origin of Life and the search for life in the Universe are topics of great public interest, this work contributes to public engagement with science as well as to the training of many young scientists.

This project involves experimental studies aimed at attaining a better understanding of the chemical reaction mechanisms involved in non-enzymatic template-directed RNA replication. The methodology involves modern structural methods such as X-ray crystallography and NMR spectroscopy, together with reaction kinetics and molecular modeling. In addition, modified nucleotides that may have been present on the early earth and that may lead to faster and more accurate copying of RNA templates are being synthesized and characterized.  The project also includes investigations of high energy chemical compounds that could have supplied the energy needed to drive RNA replication. The ability to chemically replicate RNA molecules that are long enough to encode ribozyme catalysts would help in understanding how very simple living cells could be reconstituted from individual chemical components.

por.por_cntn:
The work funded under this project addresses questions related to the Origin of Life. We initially focused on the question of how the information stored in the sequence of RNA, thought to be the primordial genetic material, could have been copied into a daughter strand of RNA before the evolution of RNA polymerase enzymes, which did not exist during the origin of life.  We discovered that efficient RNA copying proceeds through a previously undetected covalent intermediate. This intermediate consists of two nucleotides joined together by an unusual imidazolium bridge. We further studied the reaction between a growing RNA strand and the intermediate by a variety of biochemical methods; using x-ray crystallography we were able to visualize the stages of the reaction as they occurred within a crystal. These insights into the mechanism of RNA copying prompted us to examine other genetic materials that are chemically similar to RNA, and that might have been synthesized along with RNA on the early Earth.  Our experiments showed that RNA was better at copying chemistry than any of its near relatives that we examined.  This led us to propose a model for the emergence of relatively homogeneous RNA molecules from a complex mixture of prebiotic chemicals, as a consequence of repeated rounds of template copying that enrich for RNA synthesis.

 

In order for Darwinian evolution to begin, the RNA genomes of simple protocells would have had to replicate with sufficient accuracy that useful information could be transmitted from generation to generation.  However, the fidelity of RNA copying by nonenzymatic chemistry is known to be quite poor.  We have used a way of next-generation sequencing technology to sequence the products of RNA copying chemistry, in such a way that we can measure the frequency of copying errors in all possible sequence contexts. Remarkably, when copying occurs via the dinucleotide intermediate described above, it is more accurate then when copying occurs through direct reaction with monomers.  Future work will be aimed at improving the accuracy of RNA copying chemistry.

 

Our understanding of how RNA copying reactions and even RNA replication may have taken place on the early Earth is gradually becoming more complete as we integrate activation chemistry into the overall scheme. The continuation of this research may lead to the first coherent view of how RNA and then life emerged from the chemistry of our young planet.

 

Through public lectures and other outreach activities, this project has contributed to improving public knowledge and understanding of the origin of life. This is a topic of great public interest, in part because of the excitement about whether there might be life on some of the many newly discovered exoplanets, many of which are thought to have environments that could sustain life. This project has helped to stimulate public interest in and understanding of these fundamental scientific questions.
